title: Potential and Challenges of Business - Academia Partnerships

author: Martin Grabert, The Group of Eight Ltd

segmentation: Thank you very much for us.
It's a pleasure to be here and it is a pleasure to to present.
The findings of the.
Discussions we had on.
Potential and challenges.
Of business academia collaboration.
We had a very lively discussion.
The table was shared by Roman Glaza and to upload it to report on this here, I will be very brief.

We had an extensive discussion around the topic to which extent efficient and effective collaboration between academia and business fosters competitivity in the regional or even up to the global context.
I do not want to go into details.
We prepared a written report which you will find probably in the process.
Meetings I will just come up with three slides of what we call policy recommendations for three actors.
Perhaps some of these aspects can be still introduced in the.
Oceans.
Later on.

I think some are rather trivial motherhood statements here, but nevertheless I think it is important that there we we try to identify avenues for establishing new collaborations or encouraging people to try new ways.
For instance, establishing joint PhD programs.
An intern ships are a very important aspect of facilitating the interaction which, from the industry or business side very much is focused on the human resources aspects of the.
Future development in the innovation cycle.
This was certainly a complemented by view or suggestions for the private sector, the business side.
To encourage them to look into these propositions, one important aspect of our discussion, nevertheless.
Looked into the govern.
Inside and here we have some.
Recommendations as well.
These, I think are very important.
Perhaps for governments on all levels?
It is essential that.
Elected governments.
Maybe even spanning beyond their mandate.
Need to define long term objectives for.
The country these national priorities.
Need to be secured in terms of a long term investment and not.
To be subject to a whatever you call it saving debate next year, reliable policy orientation is essential for collaboration to become effective in a knowledge based economy.
Also, an important factor is the level of advice governments receive so far.
In many countries you have chief scientists advising the research Minister.
But there are only very very few examples of advice given on the cabinet level.
I think this is a breakthrough with the example in Canada because nothing works without the finance minister to be convinced that investments in.
Knowledge.
Creation and.
Interactions between the different sectors are essential for the economic prosperity.
We also got back and I'm very happy that completely uncoordinated this again comes back to the school or children aspects.
We just discussed moments ago.
The stimulation of interest and creativity in schools is in in central aspect of this evolving new way of interacting and making business in the entire world.
So we are a bit concerned around the table.
Everybody actually there to in schools, the students, the pupils are not.
Prepared appropriately.
To cope or to be confronted with the actual challenges.
And we all reported on in general terms, lack of motivation in the wealthy Western countries to engage in ciety and to take risks in business.
We also identified the fact that senior officials need a lifelong learning training in terms of what innovation in the knowledge economy means.

This certainly goes along with a cabinet level advice, and I think it is essential that governments are encouraged to interact with academia and with business as well more closely to make this happen in reality.

And we think that an open dialogue between academia and the private sector needs to be structured in a way that the curricula which are taught at the University and of which internship should be an automatic part of need to be structured and then implement it on rather short notice.
I know that this is a major handicap because curricula normally are.
An academic here, but I think we are beyond this state of debate and I hope that these recommendations will trigger a wider debate.
Now, with the chairman permitting me, I would like to give some other general remarks.
From an Australian perspective on the global human capital developments.
I just moved to Australia.
Some.
Months ago and I made some observations working with a group of eight, which is a think tank for the 8.
Research intensive University in Australia.
First, the group of eight you see here.
There are seven universities in the top 200 from the Zhaotong survey in 2010.
These seven are all members of this group.
Um I.
Had the chance to analyze Higher Education Funding in Australia, but more in detail and we see a big change here over the six years.
Or 70 years basically you you see that the contribution by students?
To the higher education to their own education is increasing drastically and I think this trend will continue.
Commitment by the public.
Or that the public to fund universities is on the decline.
In Australia presently there are about 600,000 foreign students in different levels of the educational sector.
Alot is is better ducation but about 240,000 are enrolled in the universities and they are the third biggest.
Economic factor in the trade balance of Australia.
The first is coal and iron ore. 2nd is tourism and 3rd is education.
This therefore, is an important factor in the.
Thai economy of the.
Australian nation another interesting aspect I would like to share with you is something we observe.
Not only Australia but we have a rapidly aging academic workforce.
Here the shaded part is the 2008 situation, whereas the outline is 2006.
So we have a rapid aging situation and we do very little I I'm afraid.
To build up a more healthy pyramids, which becomes now an urgent.
Yeah, policy item.
If we look at the innovation situation in.
Australia, you see here an overview.
This is public.
The.
Gross value.
Adding is here the size of the bubbles and you see the percentage.
How many businesses are considered to be innovative in Australia you see that a lot of these are related directly to services.
There's very little what you might call technical innovation, and I think this is very little, but.
A smaller dimension, and this refers again very much to the discussion previously.
The.
Global.
CG of knowledge is shifting.
If I may use Mac Arthurs map with a different perspective, we we see.
Clearly where the centers in the few.
RI have some citation here.
I just want to share that.
I hope this presentation will be made available to you as well.
Here's some report from.
And.
I people or resource supplying company.
Bloom in Shanghai they.

They employ 1000 people a year.
Another fact in.

And Europe produced.

It is 351 thousand.
This is.
In 2010, Australia produced the outrageous number 6401 engineers in this year, which shows that there is danger.
We have a shift of these competencies towards.
Other parts of the.
Teacher 1 citation.
I could not skip here.
From Senator Kay Hudson last year it speaks for itself.
I think I do not have to add anything we we have debated these aspect.
Very thoroughly, let me give you another figure which is based on group of eight studies and the National Science Foundation.
Science and engineering indicators.
Last year you see here the blue curve up there is the public number of PHD's in the United States divided by US citizen and foreign students use.
You see that first citizens now are a higher proportion than the US citizens in the United States.
Together they still generate an enormous number of.
Human capital, but you see that China already in 2006 was catching up very quickly and I can assure you that this trend continued.
And crossed the blue line.
I think two years ago.
You see the other countries quite interesting trends.
From my point of view, what a very clear message in the overall concept.
Elation let me go back to an established company General Electric every year publishes a an innovation barometer.
Very nice company view on the innovation process in the world around the world.
More than 10,000 companies have been interviewed to produce this paper, which I recommend to read very carefully.
One of the important findings which has changed over the years considerably is that according to this survey.
Only network partners.

In the future, will drive the innovation process no longer a single company, not a combination of individuals, but a combination of institutional partnerships networked in a very efficient and objective driven consolation.
I think one has to take note of this development and adjust policies.
Accord.
Let me conclude with six observations.
Urgent changes from my point of view are needed in the entire innovation and education system in the Western countries if.
The West intends to maintain leading role in this game.
The political culture in our countries must return to a reality based.
Truthful interaction with the public.
We see a kind of a deterioration of the political culture in many countries and the whole thing reminds you of a kind of a soap opera.
Where the media in with their polls every morning dictate what the policy in the afternoon will be.
I think that this.
Does not serve democracy and will certainly need to be changed in an urgent way.
New enlightenment we called it.
Thanks to Bill Adam this came up on our drive here to.
A wonderful marble knew enlightenment should be.
The driving force to establish a constructive political consensus with a long term vision of what?
Mankind basically needs despite.
Political divergences and last but not least, the entire world is a system a very complex system.
As we all know.
So the approach is to develop policies, need a similar system systematic approach.
And all this can only be achieved be achieved through the establishment of trusted global partnerships.
And.
I hope I did not stretch my time too long.
Thank you very much for your attention.
